This video seems to reflect both a lack of understanding of modern debate 
and of modern academia. Given this post, I would question whether Mr. 
Schiff actually has engaged in the slightest attempt to interpret that 
debate. Perhaps he should take a queue from the massive amounts of work it 
took Towson and Oklahoma to get to finals and go beyond a Google search and 
5 minutes of poorly clipped together footage in terms of his research.

Why does speaking fast or relating to the topic differently not constitute 
a debate? Both sides argued an academically researched position. In fact, 
some of the clips shown are actually the debaters reading segments of books 
and articles written by PhDs and academics (which was conveniently not 
mentioned). 

If the issue is that they are talking quickly, then you should read some of 
the research on this question. It actually improves information processing. 
Here is an example, if you can run 20 miles in 10 minutes, then it should 
be easy to run 10 miles in 10 minutes. The same is true in terms of 
debate's applicability to the outside world. If you can speak and process 
300 words per minute to an audience, then public speaking or information 
processing at a conversational pace is quite a bit easier.

If the issue is that they did not talk about the topic, then you should 
listen to their argument. Oklahoma actually has a very interesting way of 
relating it to the topic. By the way, lots of white teams have not talked 
about the topic but oddly none of them seem to get nearly as much negative 
media backlash. I wonder why…?

It is fine to disagree with their argument or its pedagogical benefits -- 
that is the purpose of debate after all. However, the position that this 
“wasn’t a debate” is untenable and frankly racist. Sure Schiff did not make 
a comment directly attacking black people, but he may as well have. The 
assertion that this is "why America is a nation in decline" is a classic 
blame the minorities while drumming up patriotism move. 

Believe it or not well-read college students who willingly use their free 
time to participate in academic activities do.

By the way, if you cared to find out why the comments were actually 
disabled, then you would know it is because white kids were posting racial 
slurs.

P.S.
I’ve read some of the other comments on this post so I know most of you are 
probably going to disagree with everything I just wrote. However, think "at 
the end of the day what did this video do?" It didn’t engage the debate 
community. It didn’t offer way to better the world. It didn’t offer a way 
to better debate. Literally all his post did was diminish the 
accomplishments of the four individuals in the debate round. What possible 
justification (other than Mr. Schiff wanting views) could there be for him 
just attacking college students and leaving it at that? ﻿

Honestly, I have thought a lot about what "crap" I am defending. I have 
spent years and read a considerable amount of literature. I ultimately came 
to the conclusion that debate is more beneficial than otherwise. I 
recognize that there are two sides to the coin. Hopefully, you will too.

These debates are actually not adjudicated based upon number of arguments 
made. In fact, it is almost always a losing strategy to try and explain a 
lot of different arguments in a short final speech. 

If you watch the original video, you will see that Towson only makes one 
argument in their first speech -- that narratives of pain hurt the 
affirmative's emancipatory endeavor -- but they defend that argument from a 
variety of angles. In the later speeches, they focus down even more. Speed 
can be used for depth as much as breadth. Also it truly does help 
information processing.

It is not that I think you cannot understand what is being said. Rather, I 
do not think Schiff did. My intention was more to point out the racial 
nature of his post than anything. 

If you think speed is bad then that is fine. There is no mandate anyone go 
that fast in debate. Speed itself is up for debate. However, I do think 
what Schiff posted is pretty racially charged. Look at some of the posts 
from other commentators below, I think the obscenely racist nature of many 
of the comments says something about the video and the way he presented it.

If you are attempting to misappropriate the word "debate" to apply it to a 
"competition in verbosity" then you are among the reasons why America is 
dying.  Your assumption that people do not understand what is being said, 
or that they are not bright enough to "get" what is going on is both an ad 
hominem and a non sequitur.  

Clearly, Idiocracy is real.  Partly for the existence of this nonsense 
being called a 'debate,' and partly for people like you who are trying to 
defend this as though it were an intellectual endeavor rather than the 
fireworks show it really is.

You will notice that I have not criticized the people performing here. 
 They are simply playing by the stupid rules that they were given.  That 
does not justify the practice of calling hyperverbosity a "debate."  

It is not as though I were ignorant of debate or incapable of cogent

being that I served in the NC State Legislature and have participated in

As someone who does debate in high school, I'd like to clear a few things 
up.
1) We speak quickly because we have a lot of arguments and a lot of 
information that we need to fit into timed speeches. In the past, we spoke 
at a conversational pace; this meant that points were underdeveloped and 
generally unwarranted. Also, we only speak at this pace when we know that 
the judges and competitors are trained to understand it and are comfortable 
doing so. Trust me, we can understand what we're saying; in fact, it allows 
us to have much more rigorous and in-depth debate. 
2) If you had listened to the rest of these teams speeches, you would know 
that their arguments went beyond just rapping and saying "niggas." The 
Oklahoma team's performance of rap also included arguments about why it's 
important to understand not only what war powers *do*, but how they affect 
those in impoverished, often Black communities. Further, they argue that 
purely rational argument is insufficient to capture that, which is why they 
rap, to communicate how it *feels* for the government to use war powers 
against them. I'm not sure what the winning team ran, but it's apparent 
that they introduced a discussion of how Black Americans experience 
sexuality and sexual repression. 
I'm extremely disappointed by the unthinking prejudice going on in this 
comment section. ﻿
